posts.name: joemost
posts.cooked:
One of my favorite things to do post-FIRST Robotics Competition season is look around at what other teams did. Last year, it was interesting to learn about the aprilTag mapping tools teams implemented.  

The big question is: What cool things did you do in software this year?  

(Or wait, maybe, what cool features did you see in software this year, if it was something from another team!)

posts.name: Roman A.
posts.cooked: GTSAM: Beyond the standard 4 camera PV (Photon Vision) open-source vision library-based april tag detection system we've been using for several years, this year we implemented a factor-graph system for pose estimation using GTSAM on the Nvidia Jetson Orin Nano Super Coprocessor. We utilized a StereoLabs ZED 2i depth camera on our robot, which featured a CUDA-accelerated backend, enabling automated pickup during teleop by determining the 3D position and orientation relative to our camera for coral. This setup allows for a 'single-click' pickup process, achieving nearly 60fps with a full FP32 model. Our teleop automation includes dynamic obstacle avoidance with preprogrammed sequences for scoring, climbing, and coral intake. Additionally, we developed a custom button board for operator input, granting control over various functions while maintaining smart buttons on controllers. Honorable mentions include LEDs proving unexpectedly useful, complex motion logic, and a 200-line class for simultaneous button commands.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: 5104 BreakerBots | Software and Additive Mfg. Lead

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: I saw some teams use Choreo for straight-line trajectories. It was massive overkill for this year’s game. 6995 used ChoreoLib’s auto routine sequencing to create a “flex auto” where the routine was fully defined by the start position, the scoring alignment poses, and the intake position. If Choreo trajectories existed between each consecutive pair of points, the code would just string them together with proper scoring actions. With pure PID or profiled drivetrain PID we could have done the same thing, but having Choreo for straight lines was useful for library consistency and having options to adjust individual paths.

posts.name: joemost
posts.cooked: GTSAM appears to be gaining traction in my experience, and I'm curious to hear about your experiences there.

Depth Camera: We used a StereoLabs ZED 2i depth camera on our robot, which allowed us to fully automate intakeing in ground during teleop by measuring the true 3D position and angle relative to our camera for coral. This enabled a “single click” pickup sequence, ensuring easy coral handling from any angle. Achieved nearly 60fps with a full FP32 model.  

I’ve heard of 900 and some others talking about this camera. Mind posting more details of your setup and back end?

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: 5104 BreakerBots | Software and Additive Mfg. Lead

posts.name: Roman A.
posts.cooked: Ofc! We built our backend on the Stereolabs Python SDK with integrated visualization tools and a Flask-based remote viewer. We also used CuPy for GPU acceleration of user-space tasks such as coral orientation estimation. Everything is posted to NT and read by our robot-side API. Our backend supports both the ZED 2 and X series, though due to cost-related reasons, we primarily use the ZED 2i. The hardware setup is straightforward; the camera is connected via USB to our Jetson. There isn't much complexity there. We operate at 720p resolution with neural network-assisted disparity estimation. Our primary model is a YOLOv8n detection system running through the Stereolabs SDK, utilizing CUDNN-based inference for accurate object detection. Here’s our Jetson-side application (if you’re interested). Additionally, this project’s GitHub repository provides a Python interface for interacting with ZED cameras suitable for FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) teams.

link_counts.title: GitHub - BreakerBots/ZED_FRC: ZED depth camera interface for FRC robots

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: 5104 BreakerBots | Software and Additive Mfg. Lead

posts.name: Geoffrey
posts.cooked: Five AI systems developed for the project include a custom setpoint generator for swerve that calculates feed-forward value using a simple motor model, a path planning algorithm that plans the trajectory for the superstructure including one that absorbs algae into the net, a custom vision system running on a Jetson Orin Nano that uses PyTorch multiprocessing, a coral pose estimator that calculates the angle of a coral using its bounding box, and a self-driving agent trained using reinforcement learning on a simulator that didn’t quite work yet.

posts.name: Harrison
posts.cooked:
For a basic 1-person software lead/team:
- Trying out QuestNav (currently in offseason)
- Rewrote all code to use Akit (currently in offseason)
- Maintained a Swerve/Vision template repo to support two other teams globally
- Custom programmed a Python dashboard running on a Samsung tablet acting as a second screen for our operator to handle tasks like navigating the drive coach, selecting left/right poles, or monitoring algae. This dashboard communicates with network tables when the reef automation button is pressed
- Side note: Attempting to run the dashboard on an old Zebra industrial iPad caused lag issues
We did custom stuff for anything we could get our hands on such as custom swerve custom auto pathing software and custom math functions.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.cooked: I had a potential field pathfinder for autos/teleop autoalign, a modification created by @Amicus1, which many others copied. It led our team to win IIC at MOSE Central Missouri. Additionally, I developed a fully modular auto system enabling navigation to any reef location in any order, requiring only source definitions and reef location inputs. This system achieved L4 coral reliability. Although I also created a similar algae auto system, it wasn't utilized due to unforeseen circumstances. Our first year with PhotonVision featured suboptimal camera placement causing occasional issues, yet overall operations were flawless, providing reliable autoalign functionality.

The text describes using linear algebra for a reefs alignment system by changing the basis of the error vector from standard (x,y) coordinates to depth and lateral coordinates relative to an AprilTag. A PID controller was implemented on these errors, allowing lateral movement to be faster than depth convergence. This meant the robot primarily moved forward by the end of alignment. The math involves decomposing the error vector into depth (D) and lateral (L) components, where D = [cosθ, sinθ] and L = [-sinθ, cosθ], ensuring orthogonality. Solving for coefficients d and l involved matrix inversion, resulting in d = a cosθ + b sinθ and l = -a sinθ + b cosθ. A PID controller was then applied to d and l individually with distinct KP values.
